The high season for the 2014 midterm elections is upon us, and Republicans are increasingly confident that when election day closes, the GOP will control both Houses of Congress.
That raises an important question.
In this time of polarization and gridlock, what difference would it make?
NPR's national political correspondent Mara Liasson explores that question.
This midterm election doesn't seem to be about anything in particular other than whether you like President Obama or not.
There's no overarching issue, no competing national agendas.
Instead, it's just a series of very expensive, brutally negative races for Congress.
Here's former Democratic Senate aide Jim Manley.
I'm not so sure it's going be a referendum on anything, but what it is all about, I would respectfully suggest, is who controls the Senate for the next two years.
And that's about it.
It's all about who controls the Senate.
The House is not expected to change hands.
But since nothing much happens in the Senate now under a narrow Democratic majority, why would things be any different under a narrow Republican majority?

On Sunday on ""Meet The Press"" President Obama tried to answer that question, saying the fate of his agenda on issues like the minimum wage, equal pay and infrastructure hangs in the balance if he doesn't even have one chamber of Congress making his arguments.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
I know that, you know, given the gridlock that we've seen over the last couple of years, it's easy to say that these midterms don't matter.
But the fact of the matter is that on every issue that's important to middle class Americans, overwhelmingly we're seeing a majority prefer the Democratic option.
From the Republican point of view, putting a break on that Democratic agenda would be a positive outcome.
Scott Reed, the senior political strategist at the U.S.
Chamber of Commerce, says a lot would change with a Republican Senate.
I wouldn't go so far as to call it a mandate, but I'd call it a step in the right direction.

The president will be - and the White House team will be focused on legacy, legacy, legacy.

Those things might include compromises on immigration or energy, but so far the Republican leadership has not laid out a governing agenda.

He goes on to say he'll put riders on spending bills that only need 50 votes to pass.
That strategy would set up a series of confrontations with the president - Scott Reed.
There will be an opportunity to pass some bills and send them to the president where he'll have the opportunity to either veto them or not.

So, if the Senate changes hands, one thing won't change - gridlock.
It may be more dramatic and clarifying than the gridlock we have today, but gridlock all the same, and it will set the table for the 2016 presidential elections.
